formats.name: micro_manifesto
formats.instruction: Declare your personal philosophy or life motto in exactly 20 words. No explanations, just the statement.

formats.name: reverse_interview
formats.instruction: Pose three questions as if interviewing an expert, then answer them yourself in short bursts. Total response should not exceed 90 words.

formats.name: comic_strip_caption
formats.instruction: Describe an imaginary four-panel comic strip—just the captions and brief setting, as if storyboarding a scene. Maximum 60 words.

formats.name: time_machine_postcard
formats.instruction: Write a short message (like a postcard) as if you’ve traveled 50 years into the future. Include a surprising detail or observation. 40-55 words.

formats.name: sensory_walkthrough
formats.instruction: Describe an experience entirely through sensations and feelings—no factual explanation, just what you saw, heard, smelled, touched, tasted. Minimum 120 words.

formats.name: fictional_debate
formats.instruction: Write a mini-debate between two fictional characters (real or invented) about a real-world topic. Max 230 words; include at least 3 back-and-forth exchanges.

formats.name: parallel_universe_premise
formats.instruction: Invent a scenario from a parallel universe—describe how one thing is radically different. Be vivid and specific. Aim for 60-85 words.

formats.name: emotional_autopsy
formats.instruction: Dissect a moment when you felt a strong emotion. Break it down analytically—what triggered it, what you did, what you learned. Minimum 200 words.

formats.name: wiki_entry_remix
formats.instruction: Write a playful, incorrect Wikipedia summary for a familiar topic, mixing real info with exaggerated fiction. 100-140 words.

title_styles: Craft a title as a question a child might ask. Examples: 'Why do trees talk to each other?'
Make the title sound like breaking news: 'Giant snails spotted near the local park—What does it mean?'
Channel the energy of a diary entry: 'Today I accidentally learned about quantum foam and lost track of time'
Write the title as if you're pitching a movie: 'When Robots Decide to Go on Vacation'
Pose the title as a wild hypothesis: 'What if sleep was actually a form of time travel?'
structure_variants: Alternate between bullet points and full sentences for each idea.
Frame the post as a letter to a historical figure.
Use a timeline — start at one moment and progress linearly with each paragraph.
Begin with an unexpected analogy, then unpack it step by step.
Jump back and forth between personal anecdotes and universal truths.
topic_angles: The hidden language of machines and their secret signals in public spaces
The environmental impact of everyday habits you don't think about
Re-imagining ancient myths for the digital age
Unusual forms of communication in the animal kingdom
